Description: Body sherd of large Attic black-figured pottery lid; interior glazed black (fired red) with two bands in added red; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of warrior scene (upper part of possibly collapsing bearded warrior facing left and shown in rear view; Corinthian helmet with lower part of crest attachment, corselet, added white baldric and sword hilt on right remaining; shield in profile view, with white boukranion device; at right, round shield (added red rim; device of white bird flying, to left) belonging to lost figure; at upper left corner of sherd, trace of black (possibly part of opponent); two ancient repair holes at bottom break.
Curator's comments: For parallels, see the amphora Vatican G20, dated 510-500 BC (LIMC VII sv. Kyknos I, no. 86, pl. 699). Perhaps the warrior was moving right and looking back. For parallels see the column krater Leiden, Rijksmus 19541.1, dated 525-500 BC (ABV, 263, no. 9; LIMC VII sv. Kyknos I, no. 78, pl. 698). For parallels regarding the white bird, compare the Leiden column-krater cited above.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 346, no. B428)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0835) (Phase 1)
